translated_dialog: Whatever I speak, I'll risk my life to prove it true. Mowbray has received eight thousand gold coins as a loan to pay your highness' soldiers, which he's embezzled for his own ill ends, like a false traitor and a con man. Besides I say and will in battle proveeither here or elsewhere, in the farthest place that an Englishman ever sawthat Mowbray is responsible for all the treasonous plots devised in this land for the past eighteen years. Furthermore, I say (and further will prove by challenging him in combat) that he plotted the Duke of Gloucester's death by putting his easily-persuaded enemies up to it, and consequently, like a traitorous coward, parted the innocent soul from its resting place as the blood flowed out of his body. His blood, like Abel's, cries out to me for justice and vengeance even from the silent depths of the earth; and, by all my ancestors, I'll do it with my two hands, or I'll die instead.
og_response: How high a pitch his resolution soars!Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?

translated_dialog: Yes, you want to leave so you can join Richmond. But I won't trust you.
og_response: Most mighty sovereign,You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.I never was nor never will be false.

translated_dialog: My lord, from Oxford I've sent the heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely to Londonthey were two of the dangerous traitors that plotted against you.
og_response: Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot;Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.

translated_dialog: He will die.
og_response: Hard fate! he might have died in war.    My lords, if not for any parts in him    Though his right arm might purchase his own time    And be in debt to none   yet, more to move you,    Take my deserts to his, and join 'em both:    And, for I know your reverend ages love    Security, I'll pawn my victories, all    My honours to you, upon his good returns.    If by this crime he owes the law his life,    Why, let the war receive 't in valiant gore    For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

translated_dialog: Sir Toby, I must be plain with you. My lady told me to tell you that she lets you stay here because you're her relative, but she doesn't approve of your disorderly behavior. If you can start cleaning yourself up, you are welcome to stay in the house, but if not, and you would prefer to leave, then my lady would be glad to bid you farewell.
og_response: (sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.

translated_dialog: Why, this must have been modeled on a porridge bowl! It's like a velvet dish! For shame, for shame, it's worthless and filthy! Why, it's like a cockleshell or a walnut shell, a knickknack, a trifle, a baby's cap. Take it away! Come, let me see a bigger one.
og_response: Ill have no bigger. This doth fit the time, And gentlewomen wear such caps as these.

translated_dialog: Here comes Brabantio and the brave Moor.
og_response: Valiant Othello, we must straight employ you    Against the general enemy Ottoman     [to BRABANTIO]    I did not see you. Welcome, gentle signior.    We lacked your counsel and your help tonight.

translated_dialog: [As LUCENTIO] Sir, from your clothes you seem to be a wise, respectable old gentleman, but your words show you to be a madman. Why, sir, what is it to you if I should wear pearls and gold? Thanks to my good father, I can afford it.
og_response: Thy father! O villain! He is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

translated_dialog: Its the way to behave when a scoundrel like him shows up. I wont stand him coming here.
og_response: He shall be endured.    What, goodman boy! I say, he shall. Go to.    Am I the master here, or you? Go to.    Youll not endure him! God shall mend my soul,    Youll make a mutiny among my guests.    You will set cock-a-hoop. Youll be the man!

translated_dialog: Or one of Daphne running through a thorny wood, her legs scratched up and Apollo weeping at that sad sight. The blood and tears are drawn so well you'll swear that they're real.
og_response: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord. Thou hast a lady far more beautifulThan any woman in this waning age.

translated_dialog: Oh, heaven; oh, earthwitness the words I'm going to speak. And if I speak the truth, bless them with the outcome I hope for. If Im insincere, then take all the good fortune that's in store for me and turn it bad. More than anything else in the world, I love, cherish, and honor you.
og_response: I am a foolTo weep at what I am glad of.

translated_dialog: [As VINCENTIO] You are lying. His father has already come to Padua, and here he is looking out the window.
og_response: Art thou his father?

translated_dialog: No, madam, but I'm reading the words of craziness. And if you want things done the right way, then let me do a dramatic reading.
og_response: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

translated_dialog: Wheres Potpan, whos not helping us clear the table? Has he even moved or scraped a plate?
og_response: When good manners shall lie all in one or two mens hands, and they unwashed too, tis a foul thing.

translated_dialog: That way I would improve my own company for the lack of yours.
og_response: 'Tis not well mended so, it is but botch'd;if not, I would it were.

translated_dialog: We must both give them and take them, my loving lord.
og_response: Up with my tent!Here will I lie tonight.But where tomorrow? Well, alls one for that.Who hath descried the number of the traitors?

translated_dialog: Oh, sir, if I were to deny you that service, the most just gods would send a plague of caterpillars, one for every grain we didn't give, to afflict our country. But let me ask again: can I hear the story of how your king came to be so sad?
og_response: Sit, sir, I will recount it to you:But, see, I am prevented.

translated_dialog: Let me look! If he's not my husband, my religious spirit won't let me get excited just by hearing; I'm inclined not to believe, having not seen. [She comes face to face with PERICLES] Oh, sir, are you Pericles? You spoke just like him, and you look just like him . . . did you mention a storm, a birth, and a death?
og_response: The voice of dead Thaisa!

translated_dialog: Take the fool away.
og_response: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

translated_dialog: Yes, so we will.
og_response: Tell him, when that our princely father York    Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,    And charged us from his soul to love each other,    He little thought of this divided friendship.    Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

translated_dialog: My lord, he waits to speak with you in the lower courtyard, if you'll come down.
og_response: Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,    Wanting the manage of unruly jades.    In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base,    To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.    In the base court? Come down? Down, court!    down, king!    For night-owls shriek where mounting larks    should sing.

translated_dialog: Be smart and go back home.
og_response: I will not.

translated_dialog: Both, both, my girl. We were forced from our old positions by crimes, as you call them. But we were blessed in the help we received that allowed us to end up here.
og_response: Oh, my heart bleedsTo think o' th' teen that I have turned you to,Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.

translated_dialog: You missed a sight to be seen; I can't really explain it in words. They were so overjoyed that both of them were moved to tears. They looked up to heaven and held each other's hands. They looked so much alike that we could only tell them apart by their clothes! Leonteswho was about to leap out of his skin, he was so happy he found his daughtercries out, "Oh, your mother, your mother!" as if the joy made his grief new, too. He asked Polixenes for forgiveness, then hugged his new son-in-law, then hugged his daughter again, then thanked the old shepherd who stood by like an old watchman. I have never heard of anything like it. No report can fully sum it up. Description doesn't do it justice.
og_response: What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carriedhence the child?

translated_dialog: Lacking the thing which would make the hours short if I had it.
og_response: In love?

translated_dialog: There's never been a woman that was foolish and pretty. For even the stupidity of such a woman would help her find a man.
og_response: These are old fond paradoxes to make fools laugh i' th' alehouse. What miserable praise hast thou for herThats foul and foolish?

translated_dialog: And me too, good Lord!
og_response: [aside to  LUCENTIO  ]  Husht, master, heres some good pastime toward.That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.

translated_dialog: Speak freely, good man.
og_response: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

translated_dialog: I'm not very strong if some puny little man can take my sword from me. But then again, why should my honor live on after my honesty is dead? I'll let it all go.
og_response: What did thy song bode, lady?    Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan.    And die in music.    (  singing)       Willow, willow, willow        Moor, she was chaste, she loved thee, cruel Moor.    So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true.    So speaking as I think, alas, I die.

translated_dialog: Give me the pickax and the crowbar. [He takes them from BALTHASAR] Now, take this letter. Deliver it to my father early in the morning. [He gives the letter to BALTHASAR] Give me the torch. [He takes the torch from BALTHASAR] By your life, I command that no matter what you hear or see, you stay away, and do not interrupt me in my actions. Im going to go down into this tomb in part to look upon my wifes face, but more importantly, to take a precious ring from her dead finger. I must use the ring for urgent business. So go, get out of here. And if you get suspicious and return to spy on what Im doing, I swear Ill tear you limb from limb and throw your body parts around this graveyard, which is so hungry for death. The times, and my plan, are wild and savage, and I am more fierce and unstoppable than a hungry tiger or the raging sea.
og_response: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

translated_dialog: Sir, I'll tell you, since you're bringing honor into this. Listen closely and do exactly what I say as soon as I say it, otherwise you and I are both done for!
og_response: On, good Camillo.

translated_dialog: Father, I can't be that forward with a strange knight. He might be offended by the offer, since some men take women's gifts as disrespect.
og_response: How!Do as I bid you, or you'll move me else.

translated_dialog: What if she's pretty and foolish?
og_response: She never yet was foolish that was fair,For even her folly helped her to an heir.

translated_dialog: Can your servant be trusted? Have you ever heard the saying, Two men may keep a secret, but only if one is far away?"
og_response: Warrant thee, my mans as true as steel.

translated_dialog: I don't think anything in the world could change it. You're so lucky to have your young prince, Mamillius. He's the most promising kid I've ever met.
og_response: I very well agree with you in the hopes of him:   it    is a gallant child; one that indeed physics the    subject, makes old hearts fresh:   they that went on    crutches ere he was born desire yet their life to    see him a man.

translated_dialog: I'll tear Desdemona to pieces!
og_response: Nay, yet be wise, yet we see nothing done,    She may be honest yet.   Tell me but this,    Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief    Spotted with strawberries in your wifes hand?

translated_dialog: My lord, don't you think that this talkative little York was encouraged by his deceitful mother to taunt and scorn you in that outrageous manner?
og_response: No doubt, no doubt. O, tis a parlous boy,Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable. He is all the mothers, from the top to toe.

translated_dialog: That's what he's supposed to look like.
og_response: He; I know him.

translated_dialog: May each day be happier than the one that came before, until heaven, jealous of earth's good fortune in having such a king, gives you an immortal crown after death.
og_response: We thank you both: yet one but flatters us,    As well appeareth by the cause you come;    Namely to appeal each other of high treason.    Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object    Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

translated_dialog: Oh, I have enough work for you to do. Publius, Caius, and Valentine, come here!
og_response: What is your will?

translated_dialog: May heaven give us even more love and comfort as we get older.
og_response: Amen to that, sweet powers!    I cannot speak enough of this content.    It stops me here, it is too much of joy.    And this, and this, the greatest discords be    (kissing her)     That e'er our hearts shall make!

translated_dialog: Well, he's gone off to the taming school.
og_response: The taming school? What, is there such a place?

translated_dialog: They are. My strength is all tied up, as if in a bad dream. The loss of my father, the physical weakness I feel, the destruction of all my friends, the threats of this man whos captured me would be like nothing to me, if I could just look through my prison windows once a day and see this girl. I would not need to have the freedom to go anywhere else in the world. A prison like that would give me all the space I needed.
og_response: [aside]    It works!     [to FERDINAND]    Come on.     [aside]    Thou hast done well, fine Ariel!     [to FERDINAND]    Follow me.     [to ARIEL]    Hark what thou else shalt do me.

translated_dialog: Locked up togetherexactly as you commanded and just as you left them. Sir, they are prisoners in the grove of lime trees that shields your hut from bad weather. They cant budge until you release them. The king, his brother, and your brother are waiting, out of their wits. Everyone else is worried about them, and completely shocked and sad. The one you called the good old lord Gonzalo is the most upset. Tears run down his beard like melting snow from a thatched roof. Your magic has affected them so deeply that if you saw them now, youd feel bad for them.
og_response: Dost thou think so, spirit?

translated_dialog: Criticism and debauchery surround him.
og_response: He hath not money for these Irish wars,    His burthenous taxations notwithstanding,    But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.

translated_dialog: No, sir. He's healthy and stronger than most men at his age.
og_response: By my white beard,    You offer him, if this be so, a wrong    Something unfilial:   reason my son    Should choose himself a wife, but as good reason    The father, all whose joy is nothing else    But fair posterity, should hold some counsel    In such a business.

translated_dialog: All is luck, only luck. Maria once told me that Lady Olivia liked me, and I've almost heard Olivia herself say that if she should love a man, he would be someone with my personality. Besides, she treats me with more respect and admiration than anyone else in her service. So what should I think of all this?
og_response: (  aside  ) Heres an overweening rogue!

translated_dialog: He's hopeless. Let's go back and try whatever else we can do to save ourselves.
og_response: It requires swift foot.

translated_dialog: Oh, then, saint, let lips do what hands do: pray. Grant my prayer or my faith will turn to despair.
og_response: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers sake.

translated_dialog: Im not proud of what you found, but thankful for your efforts. I cant be proud of what I hate. But I can be thankful for what I hate, if it was meant with love.
og_response: How, how, how, how? Chopped logic! What is this?    Proud, and I thank you, and I thank you not,    And yet not proud?   Mistress minion you,    Thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds,    But fettle your fine joints gainst Thursday next    To go with Paris to Saint Peters Church,    Or I will drag thee on a hurdle thither.    Out, you green sickness, carrion! Out, you baggage!    You tallow face!

translated_dialog: Why, what is going on, General? Don't talk like that.
og_response: Avaunt! Be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.I swear tis better to be much abusedThan but to know t a little.

translated_dialog: My brother, your uncle, whose name is AntonioI beg you, listen carefully (oh, how could a brother be so treacherous!)was the person whom I loved more than anyone else in the world, other than you. I trusted him to manage Milan where I ruled, which at that time was the most powerful city-state in Italy. I, Prospero, was the most powerful duke, and was admired for my dignity and my unmatched knowledge of the liberal arts. Because I spent all my time absorbed in studying secret topics, I let my brother run the government and lost contact with my city. Your lying uncleare you listening to me?
og_response: Sir, most heedfully.

translated_dialog: Get your cloak and go straight to Lord Timon. Ask him to give me my money, and do not take no for an answer. Don't even stop asking for my money when he asks you to bring him to me. Tell him that I am busy with other things, and that the terms of his loans have expired and that my kindness to his delays in repaying them has damaged my credit. I do like him, but I cannot suffer for his sake. I need money right away, and I will not accept excuses, only what I am owed. Go now, and make sure to seem urgent, like you are demanding and not asking him. I am afraid that by the time every creditor tries to take back what Timon borrowed from them, he will default with nothing, left like a naked seagull after everyone has plucked a feather from his wing, despite his current brilliant, phoenix-like appearance. Go right away.
og_response: I go, sir.

translated_dialog: Sweet Captain Blunt, if it can be done without too much danger, find a way to speak with him, and give him this important note from me.
og_response: Upon my life, my lord, Ill undertake it.And so God give you quiet rest tonight!

translated_dialog: I'll believe both those things too. And if there's anything else that seems like it can't be real, just come to me and Ill swear its true. Travelers have never told lies, even if fools back home accuse them of making things up.
og_response: If in Naples    I should report this now, would they believe me?    If I should say, I saw such islanders    For, certes, these are people of the island    Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet note,    Their manners are more gentle-kind than of    Our human generation you shall find    Manynay, almost any.

translated_dialog: Ill speed through the air in front of me, and I'll be back before your heart beats twice.
og_response: All torment, trouble, wonder, and amazementInhabits here. Some heavenly power guide usOut of this fearful country!

translated_dialog: Ill give him equal thanks, so were even.
og_response: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy    Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more    To blazon it,   then sweeten with thy breath    This neighbor air, and let rich musics tongue    Unfold the imagined happiness that both    Receive in either by this dear encounter.

translated_dialog: They've treated me like their property here, kept me in the darkness, sent their minions after methose asses!and done all they could to drive me insane by pretending I was insane.
og_response: Advise you what you say. The minister is here.   [in the voice   of Sir Topas]   Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore! Endeavor thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble-babble.

translated_dialog: This island contains everything that is good for life.
og_response: True. Save means to live.

translated_dialog: Padua contains nothing that isn't pleasant.
og_response: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

translated_dialog: She speaks my language! God, Im the highest-ranking person of all the people who speak this language. If only we were back where its spoken.
og_response: How? The best?What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee?

translated_dialog: Tell Bagot to come in. [Bagot enters.] Now, Bagot tell me honestly: what do you know about noble Gloucesters deathwho conspired with the king? Who committed the murder?
og_response: Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.

translated_dialog: Good to see you, Sir Hortensio. Do you know where I'm going? To see Baptista Minola. I promised that I would find a teacher for the fair Bianca, and my good luck has led me to this young man. His manners and learning are well-suited for her needs, and he's well-read in poetry and other booksgood books, I assure you.
og_response: 'Tis well. And I have met a gentleman    Hath promised me to help me to another,    A fine musician to instruct our mistress.    So shall I no whit be behind in duty    To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

translated_dialog: [To RIVERS] Don't try to argue with her. She's a lunatic.
og_response: Peace, Master Marquess, you are malapert.    Your fire-new stamp of honor is scarce current.    O, that your young nobility could judge    What twere to lose it and be miserable!    They that stand high have many blasts to shake them,    And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

translated_dialog: Then let your eyes be the witness of their evil. [He shows his arm] See how I am bewitched! Look at how my arm has shriveled up like a withered tree branch. This is the work of King Edward's wife Elizabeththat monstrous witchand her associate, that whorish Jane Shore. They've done this to me with their witchcraft.
og_response: If they have done this deed, my noble lord

translated_dialog: Then I hope you will not kill me.
og_response: Humh!

translated_dialog: What do you want from me?
og_response: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine lives,that I mean to make bold withal, and, as you shall use me hereafter, dry-beat the rest of the eight.   Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears? Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.

translated_dialog: Oh God, my soul senses some evil coming! It seems to me that, standing down there as you are, you look as if you are lying dead in the bottom of a tomb. Either my eyesight is failing me, or you look pale.
og_response: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!

translated_dialog: An inappropriate kiss!
og_response: Or to be naked with her friend in bedAn hour or more, not meaning any harm?

translated_dialog: [Singing]Come onto these yellow sands,And then take my hands.When youve curtsied, and kissedThe wild waves into quietness.Step lightly here and there,And, sweet spirits, carryThe burden. Listen, listen!
og_response: [dispersedly, within]  Bow-wow.

translated_dialog: May the gods' will be done! Get back on board the boat; I'll be back in a minute.
og_response: Make your best haste, and go notToo far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather;Besides, this place is famous for the creaturesOf prey that keep upon't.

translated_dialog: Stop, for God's sake!
og_response: Hold, ho! Lieutenantsir, Montanogentlemen,    Have you forgot all place of sense and duty?    Hold! The general speaks to you. Hold, for shame!

translated_dialog: At least two hours past. We must treat the time between now and six o'clock as precious, and waste none of it.
og_response: Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,    Let me remember thee what thou hast promised,    Which is not yet performed me.

translated_dialog: Nathaniel's coat wasn't ready, sir, and Gabriel's shoes didn't have the proper pattern on them. Peter's hat was the wrong color, and Walter's dagger needed a sheathe. The only ones properly dressed were Adam, Rafe, and Gregory. The rest looked like ragged old beggars. But here they are sir, and they've come as they are to greet you.
og_response: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.

translated_dialog: All right then, you do what you want. I won't go today, or tomorrow either. I won't go until I feel like it. The door is open, sir. There's the way out. You'd better get an early start. As for me, I'll leave when I want to. If you throw your weight around so rudely at the very start, I'm sure you'll prove to be a surly, overbearing husband.
og_response: O Kate, content thee. Prithee, be not angry.

translated_dialog: The chaplain of the Tower has buried them. But to tell you the truth, I don't know where.
og_response: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after-supper,    When thou shalt tell the process of their death.    Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,    And be inheritor of thy desire.    Farewell till then.

translated_dialog: Hello. What time is it?
og_response: Labouring for nine.

translated_dialog: Here comes the man who rescued me, sir.
og_response: That face of his I do remember well.    Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared    As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.    A baubling vessel was he captain of,    For shallow draught and bulk unprizable,      With which such scathful grapple did he make    With the most noble bottom of our fleet,    That very envy and the tongue of loss    Cried fame and honor on him.   Whats the matter?

translated_dialog: Kindness pours out of him. Even Plutus, the god of gold, seems like just a mere apprentice of Timon's. There is no service given him that he does not repay seven times in value. There is no gift he receives that doesn't return to the giver a sense of value exceeding the price paid for it.
og_response: The noblest mind he carriesThat ever govern'd man.

translated_dialog: Oh, Paulina, I want to believe that she lives. No perception of reality could be as blissful as that kind of insanity. Leave it alone.
og_response: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: butI could afflict you farther.

translated_dialog: It's my husband's. I remember being set in the sea right after I gave birth, but don't know how I washed up here. Since I'll never see my husband, King Pericles, again, I'll become a nun and will never be happy again.
og_response: Madam, if this you purpose as ye speak,    Diana's temple is not distant far,    Where you may abide till your date expire.    Moreover, if you please, a niece of mine    Shall there attend you.

translated_dialog: It's just and reasonable to want to take revenge on the man who killed my husband.
og_response: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husbandDid it to help thee to a better husband.

translated_dialog: You're lying, you hussy. It's Hortensio, isn't it?
og_response: If you affect him, sister, here I swear Ill plead for you myself, but you shall have him.

translated_dialog: Believe me, I would rather have lost my purse full of coins. Losing my handkerchief would be enough to make my husband jealous, if he were less loyal and more of a jealous man.
og_response: Is he not jealous?

translated_dialog: Who's ringing that bell? The devil! It's going to wake up the town. For shame, lieutenant, stop or you'll never live this down.
og_response: What is the matter here?

translated_dialog: Why, gentlemen, you both do me wrong in arguing over something that is really my decision. I am no schoolboy to be whipped and disciplined. I won't be ordered about with hours and appointed schedulesI will learn my lessons as it pleases me. So to cut off all this arguing, let's sit down and figure this out.
og_response: [as LITIO]  Youll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

translated_dialog: Are you done?
og_response: My lord, she's not paced yet: you must take somepains to work her to your manage. Come, we willleave his honour and her together. Go thy ways.

translated_dialog: Im happy to see you, my lady and my wife.
og_response: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

translated_dialog: And here comes the lieutenant, right on time.
og_response: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,I may not suffer you to visit them.The king hath strictly charged the contrary.

translated_dialog: For this reason, if you want to know: because she's the chosen beloved of Sir Gremio.
og_response: That shes the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

translated_dialog: How can you be so poor and wretched and still be afraid to die? Your cheeks are thin from hunger. Starvation and oppression are visible in your eyes. Your poverty, and the contempt of others for your situation, is like a monkey on your back. The world is not your friend, and neither are the worlds laws. The world doesnt provide a law that will make you rich. So dont be poor. Break the law, and take this money. [He holds out money]
og_response: My poverty, but not my will, consents.

translated_dialog: Swear on this sword of justice that you, Cleomenes and Dion, have been to Delphos and have brought back the sealed oracle delivered to you by Apollo's priest. Swear that, since then, you have neither broken the holy seal nor read the secrets inside.
og_response: All this we swear.

translated_dialog: A guy with a reputation for hanging out with prostitutes. I know he used to be the prince's servant. He was kicked out of court for one of his virtues; I can't remember which one.
og_response: His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whippedout of the court: they cherish it to make it staythere; and yet it will no more but abide.

translated_dialog: What do you say, Juliet? Can you love this gentleman? Tonight hell be at our feast. Look at his face and delight in his beauty. Examine how all the lines of his features combine to make him handsome. And what you cant see in his beauty, find by looking in his eyes. This wonderful, loving man lacks only a bride to make him perfect. As fish do not hide from the sea, neither should a beauty like you hide from a handsome man like him. Everyone thinks hes handsome, and whoever becomes his bride would be equally loved. You would share all that he possesses, and lose nothing by having him.
og_response: No less? Nay, bigger. Women grow by men.

translated_dialog: A good reputation is the most precious jewel of a man's or a woman's soul, my dear lord. If someone steals money from me, it's not a big deal. It was mine, now it's his, and it's been held by thousands of others. But if someone steals my good reputation from me, then he really does make me truly poor, and steals something that doesn't even make him any richer.
og_response: Ill know thy thoughts.

translated_dialog: Since it's spring, sirsummer's not over yet and winter hasn't comethe prettiest flowers blooming at the moment are carnations and multicolor gillyvors, which some people call "nature's bastards." We don't grow those here, and I'm not a big fan.
og_response: Wherefore, gentle maiden,Do you neglect them?

translated_dialog: What did he ask you for?
og_response: He sent to me, sir,Here he comes.

translated_dialog: Please, my lord, there is no need for that.
og_response: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man    Can justly praise but what he does affect:    I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;    I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

translated_dialog: Neither.
og_response: Thou hast sworn my love to be.

translated_dialog: Whatever, he's poor and that's punishment enough for him. After all, who can say whatever he wants more than the man with no home and nothing to lose?
og_response: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

translated_dialog: Certainly not, in that case. You'll have the mustard or else you'll get no beef from Grumio.
og_response: Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.

translated_dialog: [Giving the FOOL money] That's for your trouble.
og_response: No pains, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.

translated_dialog: The trumpets show that the emperor is here.
og_response: What, hath the firmament more suns than one?

translated_dialog: Thank you. How is Lieutenant Cassio doing?
og_response: Lives, sir.

translated_dialog: As eagerly as I ever came home from school.
og_response: [as LUCENTIO]  And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

translated_dialog: I thank you for telling me. Here comes the duke.
og_response: Who saw Cesario, ho?

translated_dialog: Indeed, that's clear to see. I am not at ease with the discrepancy in the reports, but I understand the general idea of all of them, and it makes me worried.
og_response: [within]   What, ho, what, ho, what, ho!

translated_dialog: [To ANNE] Come, madam, come. I was sent in a great hurry.
og_response: And I in all unwillingness will go.    O, would to God that the inclusive verge    Of golden metal that must round my brow    Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!    Anointed let me be with deadly venom,    And die ere men can say, God save the Queen.

translated_dialog: Not because your eyebrows are dark, although they say dark eyebrows look good on some women. It's better if you pluck them in a semi-circle, or draw a half-moon shape with a pen.
og_response: Who taught you this?

translated_dialog: I will release you from any obligation to me.
og_response: Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well.A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

translated_dialog: If there is any such man, may God have mercy on him!
og_response: A halter pardon him and hell gnaw his bones!    Why should he call her whore? Who keeps her company?    What place? What time? What form? What likelihood?    The Moors abused by some most villainous knave,    Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.    O heavens, that such companions thoudst unfold,    And put in every honest hand a whip    To lash the rascals naked through the world    Even from the east to th' west!

translated_dialog: Please, pay attention to me. I neglected all things related to ordinary life or politics, and dedicated myself entirely to seclusion in order to improve my knowledge of topics that have more value than is commonly believed. But by cutting myself off from the world, I unknowingly awoke evil in the heart of my brother. Like a good parent who raises a bad child, my trust in him produced the opposite effect, making him into a liar as big as my trust in him wasand my trust in him had no limit. My confidence in him was infinite. Now established in his position of power, and able to use all of my wealth (and whatever wealth he could use my power to take for himself), he became like a man who told a lie for so long that he began to believe it was true. He began to believe he was actually the duke. As a result of being my substitute, and acting as the royal duke in public with all the duke's rights and power, his ambition began to groware you listening?
og_response: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.

translated_dialog: Absolutely, so look after that handkerchief carefully.
og_response: Then would to Heaven that I had never seen t!

translated_dialog: [As LUCENTIO] I'll do you this favor for his sake, and to save your life in this dangerous situationindeed, you should consider yourself lucky that you resemble Sir Vincentio. You'll pretend to be him, assume his name and reputation, and stay at my house as a guest. Just make sure that you play your part well. Do you understand, sir? This way you can stay until you've done your business in the city. If this is kindness, then accept it.
og_response: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.

translated_dialog: And make yoursel a happy mother by doing so.
og_response: I go. Write to me very shortly,And you shall understand from me her mind.

translated_dialog: If he is dead, and we don't have a ruler, then we would hardly want the kingdom to continue this way, like a building without a roof, a country without a king is quickly ruined. With all your experience, we would look to you, and would appoint you to be our next king.
og_response: Live, noble Helicane!

translated_dialog: Who's there?
og_response: [within]  O good my lord, I would speak a word with you!

translated_dialog: I swear I will.
og_response: But, sir, here comes your boy.'Twere good he were schooled.

translated_dialog: Get out of here and go find my dog! And if you don't, I don't ever want to see you again. Go away, I say! Are you staying here to make me angry?
og_response: A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!    Sebastian, I have entertained thee,    Partly that I have need of such a youth    That can with some discretion do my business,    For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,    But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,    Which, if my augury deceive me not,    Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:    Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.    Go presently and take this ring with thee,    Deliver it to Madam Silvia:    She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

translated_dialog: On record, my gracious lord.
og_response: But say, my lord, it were not registered,    Methinks the truth should live from age to age,    As twere retailed to all posterity,    Even to the general all-ending day.

translated_dialog: Carthage?
og_response: I assure you, Carthage.

translated_dialog: No, not until Thursday. Theres enough time.
og_response: Go, Nurse. Go with her. Well to church tomorrow.

translated_dialog: [To herself] She doesn't need to doubt your bravery, because she knows that you're a coward.
og_response: What says she to my birth?

translated_dialog: Oh stop, you're being too hard on yourself. Given the circumstances, I wholeheartedly wish this hadn't happened. But it has happened, so make the best of the situation.
og_response: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard. Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all.   To be now a sensible man, byand by a fool, and presently a beast! Oh, strange! Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.

translated_dialog: I am always there for friends.
og_response: What a coil's here!    Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!    I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums    That are given for 'em.   Friendship's full of dregs:    Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs,    Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

translated_dialog: Yes, yes, my lord. Ill take you to him when he's asleep, then you can smash a nail into his head.
og_response: Thou liest. Thou canst not.

translated_dialog: Good God. And well said! A joking bastard, ha! You are a blockhead. In good faith, it's day already. The Count will be here soon with musicians, for he said he would.  I hear him coming
og_response: I hear him near.Nurse! Wife! What ho, what, Nurse, I say!

translated_dialog: You are welcome, sir! Before you depart, you'll have a wonderful time filled with many pleasures. Please, let's go inside!
og_response: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

translated_dialog: Yes, Caliban, her son.
og_response: Dull thing, I say so. He, that Caliban    Whom now I keep in service. Thou best knowst    What torment I did find thee in.   Thy groans    Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts    Of ever angry bears.   It was a torment    To lay upon the damned, which Sycorax    Could not again undo.   It was mine art,    When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape    The pine and let thee out.

translated_dialog: You make me glad. Im full of happiness. Lets have some fun. Will you sing the song you taught me a short while ago?
og_response: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason.    Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.     [sings]    Flout 'em and scout 'em,    And scout 'em and flout 'em.    Thought is free.

translated_dialog: I'm listening and my heart is ready; the worst you can say is just loss on this earth. Tell me, is my kingdom lost? Well, it was my responsibility; and what loss is it to be rid of a burden? Does Bolingbroke want to take my throne? He can never be greater; if he serves God, we're both His servants. Do our subjects rebel against us? We can't fix that, since they betray God as well as us. Go ahead, speak of  despair, destruction, ruin and decay: the worst is death, and death will have his day.
og_response: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd    To bear the tidings of calamity.    Like an unseasonable stormy day,    Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,    As if the world were all dissolved to tears,    So high above his limits swells the rage    Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land    With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.    White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps    Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices,    Strive to speak big and clap their female joints    In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:    The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows    Of double-fatal yew against thy state;    Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills    Against thy seat: both young and old rebel,    And all goes worse than I have power to tell.

translated_dialog: Take all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer, noble father-in-law. Tell me, how is my loving mother?
og_response: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother,    Who prays continually for Richmonds good.    So much for that. The silent hours steal on,    And flaky darkness breaks within the east.    In brief, for so the season bids us be,    Prepare thy battle early in the morning,    And put thy fortune to the arbitrament    Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.    I, as I maythat which I would I cannot,    With best advantage will deceive the time,    And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms.    But on thy side I may not be too forward,    Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George,    Be executed in his fathers sight.    Farewell. The leisure and the fearful time    Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love    And ample interchange of sweet discourse,    Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.    God give us leisure for these rites of love!    Once more, adieu. Be valiant, and speed well.

translated_dialog: I am rid of him, and yet more men! Hate them, Timon, and eat your food.
og_response: Where should he have this gold? It is some poor    fragment, some slender sort of his remainder:   the    mere want of gold, and the falling-from of his    friends, drove him into this melancholy.

translated_dialog: Welcome, my son; who are the violets now that celebrate the new spring?
og_response: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not:God knows I had as lief be none as one.

translated_dialog: Open it! [They succeed in loosening the lid of the chest] Shh! I smell something sweet.
og_response: A delicate odour.

translated_dialog: It is my soul that calls out my name. Lovers' voices at night sound silver-sweet, the most lovely music to lovers ears.
og_response: Romeo!

translated_dialog: What's the reason for your awful shouting? What's the matter out there?
og_response: Signior, is all your family within?

translated_dialog: She calls out my name as if it were a bullet that had been shot from a gun and murdered her, just as I murdered her cousin. Tell me, Friar, in what vile part of my body does my name rest? Tell me, so I can cut it out of myself. [He draws his dagger]
og_response: Hold thy desperate hand.    Art thou a man? Thy form cries out thou art.    Thy tears are womanish. Thy wild acts denote    The unreasonable fury of a beast.    Unseemly woman in a seeming man,    And ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!    Thou hast amazed me. By my holy order,    I thought thy disposition better tempered.    Hast thou slain Tybalt? Wilt thou slay thyself,    And slay thy lady that in thy life lives    By doing damnèd hate upon thyself?    Why railst thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?    Since birth and heaven and earth, all three do meet    In thee at once, which thou at once wouldst lose?    Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit,    Which, like a usurer, aboundst in all    And usest none in that true use indeed    Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.    Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,    Digressing from the valor of a man;    Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,    Killing that love which thou hast vowed to cherish;    Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,    Misshapen in the conduct of them both,    Like powder in a skill-less soldiers flask,    Is set afire by thine own ignorance;    And thou dismembered with thine own defence.    What, rouse thee, man! Thy Juliet is alive,    For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead    There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,    But thou slewst Tybaltthere art thou happy.    The law that threatened death becomes thy friend    And turns it to exilethere art thou happy.    A pack of blessings light upon thy back,    Happiness courts thee in her best array,    But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench,    Thou poutst upon thy fortune and thy love.    Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.    Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.    Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.    But look thou stay not till the watch be set,    For then thou canst not pass to Mantua,    Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time    To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,    Beg pardon of the Prince,   and call thee back    With twenty hundred thousand times more joy    Than thou wentst forth in lamentation.    Go before, Nurse.   Commend me to thy lady,    And bid her hasten all the house to bed,    Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.    Romeo is coming.

translated_dialog: Would there be no marriage among those he ruled?
og_response: None, man. All idle. Whores and knaves.

translated_dialog: I don't know. I found it in my bedroom, and I like the pattern on it. Before someone asks for it back, I want to have the pattern copied. Take it and do it, and leave me alone for a bit.
og_response: Leave you! Wherefore?

translated_dialog: Anyone who calls me a traitor (unless he's a king, of course) is a liar.
og_response: [Aside]  Now, by the gods, I do applaud his courage.

translated_dialog: How are you feeling now?
og_response: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

translated_dialog: I can't find my coat.
og_response: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humour sways him.He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he hasbeat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?

translated_dialog: Why Hearts Ease?
og_response: O musicians, because my heart itself plays My Heart isFull. O, play me some merry dump to comfort me.

translated_dialog: He can tell me not to do something that's wrong, but right now I'm doing the right thing. Unless he follows your example and locks me up for doing good, he can't be the boss of me.
og_response: La you now, you hear:When she will take the rein I let her run;But she'll not stumble.

translated_dialog: I don't know who started it. We were all friends just a moment ago, as close as a bride and groom going to bed. But then, just now, as if some cosmic shift of the planets had affected them, they drew their swords and started lunging at each other in a bloody fight. I can't say what was the cause of it, and I wish I didn't have the legs that brought me here to take part in it.
og_response: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?

translated_dialog: Then you go ahead, and I will follow you.
og_response: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die    Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.    Ill in to urge his hatred more to Clarence    With lies well steeled with weighty arguments,    And, if I fail not in my deep intent,    Clarence hath not another day to live;    Which done, God take King Edward to His mercy,    And leave the world for me to bustle in.    For then Ill marry Warwicks youngest daughter.    What though I killed her husband and her father?    The readiest way to make the wench amends    Is to become her husband and her father;    The which will I, not all so much for love    As for another secret close intent    By marrying her which I must reach unto.    But yet I run before my horse to market.    Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns.    When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

translated_dialog: I'm not talking to you.
og_response: No,'tis to thyself.

translated_dialog: How could I possibly understand what you're talking about?
og_response: I will unbolt to you.    You see how all conditions, how all minds,    As well of glib and slippery creatures as    Of grave and austere quality, tender down    Their services to Lord Timon:   his large fortune    Upon his good and gracious nature hanging    Subdues and properties to his love and tendance    All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer    To Apemantus, that few things loves better    Than to abhor himself:   even he drops down    The knee before him, and returns in peace    Most rich in Timon's nod.

translated_dialog: Gracious Olivia
og_response: What do you say, Cesario?Good my lord

translated_dialog: The empress, the midwife, and you: two can be silent when the third's gone. Go to the empress and tell her that.
og_response: Weke, weke! so cries a pig prepared to the spit.

translated_dialog: Faithful friends and proven warriors, I've received letters from Rome telling me how much they hate the emperor and how eagerly they look forward to our arrival. So, great lords who are impatient with the wrongs done to you, however Rome has hurt you, make sure you repay it threefold.
og_response: Brave slip, sprung from the great Andronicus,    Whose name was once our terror, now our comfort;    Whose high exploits and honourable deeds    Ingrateful Rome requites with foul contempt,    Be bold in us:   we'll follow where thou lead'st,    Like stinging bees in hottest summer's day    Led by their master to the flowered fields,    And be avenged on cursed Tamora.

translated_dialog: There's nothing more than that. When you tell me the deed is done, I will love you and promote you for it.
og_response: I will dispatch it straight.

translated_dialog: Start a fire and get some food for these poor men. It's been a rough and stormy night.
og_response: I have been in many; but such a night as this,Till now, I ne'er endured.

translated_dialog: Why, may I ask?
og_response: I dreamt a dream tonight.

translated_dialog: Because, when he swallowed me, I would have made a bunch of noise in his belly. I would have jangled all the bells so much that he wouldn't have left until he vomited up all the bells, steeple, church, and parish again. If King Simonides agreed with me
og_response: [Aside]  Simonides!

translated_dialog: [To MALVOLIO] Alas, you poor fool, how they've humiliated you!
og_response: Why, some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them. I was one, sir, in this interlude, one Sir Topas, sir, but thats all one.   [imitates MALVOLIO]   By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.   But do you remember? Madam, why laugh you at sucha barren rascal; an you smile not, hes gagged?   and thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

translated_dialog: The blessings of earth, plentiful harvests, Always full barns and silos, Vines full of clustered grapes, Plants bending under the weight of their fruitMay spring followRight after the end of autumns harvest. Lack and poverty will never touch you. That is Ceres blessing for you.
og_response: This is a most majestic vision, and    Harmonious charmingly.   May I be bold    To think these spirits?

translated_dialog: Are you speaking from your heart?
og_response: And from my soul too, else beshrew them both.

translated_dialog: Alas, what is that cry?
og_response: That? What?

translated_dialog: No, just unpin this for me here. That Lodovico is a good man.
og_response: A very handsome man.

translated_dialog: She is yours and, as the saying goes, she's like you to a fault. [To the gentlemen] Behold, gentlemen. Though she might be a smaller version, she's an exact copy of her father: eyes, nose, mouth, his usual frown, his forehead, the cheek and chin dimples, his smile, the exact shape of his hand, fingers, and nails. Hermione's given birth to her husband's mini-me, and I guarantee you she has no doubt that her children are Leontes's!
og_response: Hang all the husbandsThat cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourselfHardly one subject.

translated_dialog: All to you. More lights please!
og_response: The best of happiness,Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

translated_dialog: It's very true.
og_response: See, not a man in private conferenceOr council has respect with him but he.

translated_dialog: Look, shes back from confession looking happier.
og_response: How now, my headstrong? Where have you been gadding?

translated_dialog: Then why arent our eyelids closing? Im not feeling tired at all.
og_response: Nor I. My spirits are nimble.    They fell together all, as by consent.    They dropped, as by a thunderstroke.   What might,    Worthy Sebastian, O, what might? No more.    And yet methinks I see it in thy face,    What thou shouldst be.   Th' occasion speaks thee, and    My strong imagination sees a crown    Dropping upon thy head.

translated_dialog: Youre the kind of guy who walks into a bar, slaps his sword down on the table and says, I hope I dont have to use you. By the time hes having his second drink, he draws his sword on the bartender for no reason.
og_response: Am I like such a fellow?

translated_dialog: Well then, who will be her king?
og_response: Even he that makes her queen. Who else should be?

translated_dialog: I've had very little joy in being England's queen.
og_response: [aside]  And lessened be that small, God I beseech Him!Thy honor, state, and seat is due to me.

translated_dialog: Where are the evil instigators of this fight?
og_response: O noble prince, I can discover all    The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.    There lies the man, slain by young Romeo,    That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.

translated_dialog: Gentlemen, play some music here. I'll pay you for your trouble. Play a short song, and then say, "Good morning, general."
og_response: Why masters, have your instruments been in Naples, thatthey speak i' th' nose thus?

translated_dialog: Unless it's for that then I cannot guess, my lord.
og_response: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.Thou wilt revolt and fly to him, I fear.

translated_dialog: A husband? A devil!
og_response: I say a husband.

translated_dialog: Im not crazy; I know who you are. By my poor stump, these lines of blood, these lines of grief on my face, my exhausted days and heavy nights, and all my suffering, I know that youre our proud empress, mighty Tamora. Have you come for my other hand?
og_response: Know, thou sad man, I am not Tamora;    She is thy enemy, and I thy friend:    I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom,    To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind,    By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.    Come down, and welcome me to this world's light;    Confer with me of murder and of death:    There's not a hollow cave or lurking-place,    No vast obscurity or misty vale,    Where bloody murder or detested rape    Can couch for fear, but I will find them out;    And in their ears tell them my dreadful name,    Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.

translated_dialog: Go on ahead. I'll talk with this good fellow.
og_response: How now, sirrah! How goes the world with thee?

translated_dialog: My lord, consider it done.
og_response: [to CALIBAN]  Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himselfUpon thy wicked dam, come forth!

translated_dialog: Here's a slut who doesn't know when to shut up, who just beat her husband and is now trying to trick me! This brat is not mine, it's Polixenes's. Get it out of here, and throw it and the bitch into the fire!
og_response: It is yours;    And, might we lay the old proverb to your charge,    So like you, 'tis the worse.   Behold, my lords,    Although the print be little, the whole matter    And copy of the father, eye, nose, lip,    The trick of's frown, his forehead, nay, the valley,    The pretty dimples of his chin and cheek,    His smiles,    The very mould and frame of hand, nail, finger:    And thou, good goddess Nature, which hast made it    So like to him that got it, if thou hast    The ordering of the mind too, 'mongst all colours    No yellow in't, lest she suspect, as he does,    Her children not her husband's!

translated_dialog: Good morning to you, sir.
og_response: Doth this news hold of good King Edwards death?

translated_dialog: Should dying men flatter those that live?
og_response: No, no, men living flatter those that die.

translated_dialog: Well then, please take me to the queen.
og_response: I may not, madam:To the contrary I have express commandment.

translated_dialog: Have I waited to see this morning for so long, only for it to look like this?
og_response: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!    Most miserable hour that eer time saw    In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.    But one, poor one, one poor and loving child,    But one thing to rejoice and solace in,    And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!

translated_dialog: God bless you, sir!
og_response: And keep your mind, till you return to us,Peaceful and comfortable!

translated_dialog: Yes, sir. Some mischievous boys in the market square stole the other small dog from me. So then I offered her my own dog, who is as big as ten of yours. And therefore the gift was all the greater.
og_response: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,    Or ne'er return again into my sight.    Away, I say! Stay'st thou to vex me here?

translated_dialog: What do you want us to do, Andronicus?
og_response: Show me a murderer, I'll deal with him.

translated_dialog: I was just thinking that when we met. I hope things are not so bad that Timon has had to borrow more from his friends.
og_response: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.

translated_dialog: And tell me, how many tears were shed when you left him?
og_response: Faith, none for me;   except the north-east wind,    Which then blew bitterly against our faces,    Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance    Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.

translated_dialog: If you love him, sister, you can have him. I swear I'll even plead with him on your behalf.
og_response: Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

translated_dialog: Would anyone say "no" to that? Something incredible happens every time you blink! The longer we stay here, the less we'll see. Let's go.
og_response: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me,    would preferment drop on my head. I brought the old    man and his son aboard the prince:   told him I heard    them talk of a fardel and I know not what: but he    at that time, overfond of the shepherd's daughter,    so he then took her to be, who began to be much    sea-sick, and himself little better, extremity of    weather continuing,   this mystery remained    undiscovered. But 'tis all one to me; for had I    been the finder out of this secret, it would not    have relished among my other discredits.    [Enter Shepherd and Clown]    Here come those I have done good to against my will,    and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.

translated_dialog: Friends, can I beg for you to give me this armor? I recognize the marks; it belongs to a king who loved me, and I want to have it for his sake. Can I also ask you to lead me to the king's court? With this armor, I'll dress up like like a gentleman and, if I win and improve my bad luck, I'll pay you back for kindness. Until then, I owe you.
og_response: Why, wilt thou tourney for the lady?

translated_dialog: Great king, I present your deepest fear. Richard of Bordeaux, the greatest of your enemies, lies in this coffin, brought here by me.
og_response: Exton, I thank thee not;   for thou hast wrought    A deed of slander with thy fatal hand    Upon my head and all this famous land.

translated_dialog: This gentleman, a kinsman of the Prince and my friend, was killed while fighting on my behalf, to defend me against Tybalts insults. Tybalt, who has been my own kinsman for an hour! Oh, sweet Juliet, your beauty has made me effeminate and softened the steel of my valor.
og_response: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds,Which too untimely here did scorn the earth.

translated_dialog: Would you dare to kill a friend of mine?
og_response: Please you. But I had rather kill two enemies.

translated_dialog: Maybe you'll explode!
og_response: Away,Thou tedious rogue! I am sorry I shall loseA stone by thee.

translated_dialog: I've never tried it.
og_response: Nay, then thou wilt starve, sure; for here's nothingto be got now-a-days, unless thou canst fish for't.

translated_dialog: You may take my word, my lord. I know no man who can fairly praise more than what he likes: I count my friends' desires as my own. This is the truth. We'll see each other again.
og_response: O, none so welcome.

translated_dialog: Youve told us well; well do it. But wouldnt it be nice, good Andronicus, to send a message to your brave son Luciuswho is coming towards Rome with an army of Gothsand invite him to come for a banquet at your house? And when hes here at this feast, Ill bring the empress and her sons, the emperor himself, and all your enemies. Theyll kneel before you and beg for mercy, and you can do what you want with them. What do you think of this plan?
og_response: Marcus, my brother! 'tis sad Titus calls.

translated_dialog: Ah, poor thing!
og_response: O, good sir, softly, good sir! I fear, sir, myshoulder-blade is out.

translated_dialog: I can see in our sullen faces that all our hearts still wear the uniforms we served Timon in. We are still friends, serving him in sorrow. It is as if our boat had a leak and we were standing on the sinking deck, hearing the water rising all around us. We must all leave each other to drown in this imaginary sea.
og_response: Good fellows all,    The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you.    Wherever we shall meet, for Timon's sake,    Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say,    As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes,    'We have seen better days.'   Let each take some;    Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:    Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.

translated_dialog: Give me your hand, and let me see you in your woman's clothes.
og_response: The captain that did bring me first on shore    Hath my maids garments.   He, upon some action,    Is now in durance at Malvolios suit,    A gentleman and follower of my ladys.

translated_dialog: Listen, daughter: princes, like the gods, should be generous to anyone who comes before them. Stingy princes are like gnats; they buzz around and everyone's glad when they're killed. So, to make Pericles's stay more enjoyable, what do you say we drink a toast of this wine to him to help cheer him up?
og_response: Alas, my father, it befits not me    Unto a stranger knight to be so bold:    He may my proffer take for an offence,    Since men take women's gifts for impudence.

translated_dialog: Are you going to Lord Timon's feast?
og_response: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

translated_dialog: Truly, I can't, sir. The voyage I am determined to make is merely wandering without a destination. But I can tell that you're polite enough to not force me to tell you something I want to keep to myselfso it's only good manners for me to tell you what I can, Antonio. My name is Sebastian, though I called myself Roderigo. My father was Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you've heard of. He is dead now, but he left behind myself and my twin sister, who was born the same hour as me. If only God had allowed us to die in the same hour as well! But you, sir, kept that from happening, for my sister drowned an hour before you pulled me from the breaking waves.
og_response: Alas the day!

translated_dialog: My company is worth less than your good words. But who comes here?
og_response: It is my son, young Harry Percy,Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever.Harry, how fares your uncle?

translated_dialog: A sad story's best for winter. I know one about ghosts and goblins.
og_response: Let's have that, good sir.Come on, sit down: come on, and do your bestTo fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.

translated_dialog: [Sarcastically] Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'
og_response: Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?    Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord,    That set'st the word itself against the word!    Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;    The chopping French we do not understand.    Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there;    Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;    That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce,    Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.

translated_dialog: Nah, none of those names suits me at all. I'm as honest as you are crazy and, all things considered, that's honest enough for anyone.
og_response: Traitors!Will you not push her out? Give her the bastard.Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroostedBy thy dame Partlet here. Take up the bastard;Take't up, I say; give't to thy crone.

translated_dialog: Proceed. No one will leave.
og_response: Music, awake her; strike!  [Music]    'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach;    Strike all that look upon with marvel.   Come,    I'll fill your grave up: stir, nay, come away,    Bequeath to death your numbness, for from him    Dear life redeems you.   You perceive she stirs:    [HERMIONE comes down]    Start not; her actions shall be holy as    You hear my spell is lawful:   do not shun her    Until you see her die again; for then    You kill her double.   Nay, present your hand:    When she was young you woo'd her; now in age    Is she become the suitor?

translated_dialog: [To POLIXENES] Welcome, sir. My father has asked me to play hostess today.[To CAMILLO] You're welcome, too, sir. [To DORCAS] Give me those flowers, Dorcas . . .[To POLIXENES and CAMILLO] Gentlemen, here are some herbs for you that will stay green all winter long; rosemary and rue are a gift to symbolize grace and remembrance. And welcome to our shearing!
og_response: Shepherdess,A fair one are youwell you fit our agesWith flowers of winter.

translated_dialog: Well, I'll put it on, and I'll disguise myself in it. If only I was the first person to play the hypocrite while wearing a priest's robe.
og_response: I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student,   but to be saidan honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors enter.

translated_dialog: Did you hear that Alcibiades is banished?
og_response: Alcibiades banished!

translated_dialog: Hes a fine flower, absolutely, a flower.
og_response: What say you? Can you love the gentleman?    This night you shall behold him at our feast.    Read oer the volume of young Paris face    And find delight writ there with beautys pen.    Examine every married lineament    And see how one another lends content,    And what obscured in this fair volume lies    Find written in the margin of his eyes.    This precious book of love, this unbound lover,    To beautify him only lacks a cover.    The fish lives in the sea, and tis much pride    For fair without the fair within to hide.    That book in manys eyes doth share the glory    That in gold clasps locks in the golden story.    So shall you share all that he doth possess    By having him, making yourself no less.

translated_dialog: Oh, what a bitter conclusion that Edward should still live as the "true, noble prince!" Cousin, you didn't use to be so stupid. Shall I speak plainly? I want the bastards dead, and I want it done immediately. What do you say now? Speak quickly, and be brief.
og_response: Your Grace may do your pleasure.

translated_dialog: Well, well, he was the most secretive, hidden traitor that ever lived. Can you imagine, Lord Mayorif we hadn't been lucky enough to stop himthat sneaky traitor was plotting to murder me and the Lord of Gloucester in the council room today?
og_response: Had he done so?

translated_dialog: He's really taken our trick to heartit seems to have infected his very soul.
og_response: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.

translated_dialog: You stupid bumpkin! You bastard workhorse drudge! Didn't I tell you to meet me outside and bring these idiot rascals along with you?
og_response: Nathaniels coat, sir, was not fully made,    And Gabriels pumps were all unpinked i' th' heel.    There was no link to color Peters hat,    And Walters dagger was not come from sheathing.    There were none fine but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory.    The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly.    Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

translated_dialog: Why, a horse.
og_response: Tell thou the tale! But hadst thou not crossed me, thoushouldst have heard how her horse fell, and she under her horse.   Thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place,how she was bemoiled, how he left her with the horse upon her,   how he beat me because her horse stumbled, howshe waded through the dirt to pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed that never prayed before,   how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how I lost my crupper, with many things of worthymemory which now shall die in oblivion, and thou returnunexperienced to thy grave.

translated_dialog: They are; and Bolingbroke has imprisoned the wasteful king. Oh, it's a pity that he didn't manage his land as we take care of this garden! At this time of year, we harvest the sap from our fruit-trees, so they don't rot with over-sweetness; if he had done the same with his nobleman, they might have lived to produce the fruits of duty.  We cut away unnecessary branches, so that the more fruitful branches can live: if he had done so, he might still wear the crown which he has cast away by being so lazy and careless.
og_response: What, think you then the king shall be deposed?

translated_dialog: Yes.
og_response: He will not say so.

translated_dialog: Of course, if you love me, sir!
og_response: Even as my life, or blood that fosters it.

translated_dialog: Yet ask.
og_response: And shall I have?

translated_dialog: I'll harp on it until my heartstrings break.
og_response: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown

translated_dialog: Why, I learned my scales long ago.
og_response: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

translated_dialog: Go on.
og_response: [reads]  With a small-compassed cape

translated_dialog: I swear by heaven, I do not lie, I do not, gentlemen. [To OTHELLO] Oh, you murdering fool! How did such a fool as you get such a good wife?
og_response: Are there no stones in heavenBut what serve for the thunder?Precious villain!

translated_dialog: When all the good manners are owned by just one or two men, and even those two are dirty, its a bad thing.
og_response: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard,look to the plate. Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane,   and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.Antony and Potpan!

translated_dialog: And so am I to you.
og_response: So infinitely endear'd

translated_dialog: Good.
og_response: Let your breath cool yourself, telling your haste.

translated_dialog: What, do you want my weapon, little lord?
og_response: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

translated_dialog: Who, Mr. Syphilis?
og_response: Ay, he: he offered to cut a caper at theproclamation; but he made a groan at it, and sworehe would see her to-morrow.

translated_dialog: Never trust me again if I don't. And by all means encourage the youth to answer the knight's challenge. An oxcart couldn't haul them close enough together to fight. As for Andrew, if you dissected him and found enough red blood in his liver for even a flea to notice, I'd eat the rest of his body. He's a coward through and through.
og_response: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.

translated_dialog: [To himself] Keep on working, my harmful medicine, keep on working! This is how gullible fools are tricked, and many trustworthy and chaste women, completely innocent, are punished in situations like this. [To OTHELLO] Hey! My lord! My lord! Othello!
og_response: How now, Cassio!

translated_dialog: We'll do it thensome dogs are good at playing catch.
og_response: Most certain. Let our catch be Thou Knave.

translated_dialog: [She gives BOULT a coin] Boult, spread the news in town about our new guest, and don't leave out a single detail. When Mother Nature put together this girl, she meant to do you a favor. If you tell everyone how beautiful she is, you'll get money and you'll get to sleep with her, too.
og_response: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awakethe beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stir upthe lewdly-inclined. I'll bring home some to-night.

translated_dialog: A dry one, sir.
og_response: Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But whats your jest?

translated_dialog: Yes, leave that labor to great Herculesit's worse than all the other Twelve Labors put together.
og_response: [To TRANIO]   Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth:    The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for,    Her father keeps from all access of suitors    And will not promise her to any man    Until the elder sister first be wed.    The younger then is free, and not before.

translated_dialog: [To himself] I can't change his mind; he's decided to leave. I could make this work to my advantage and keep him safe, all the while being loyal to him and to Polixenes. This could be my chance to see Leontes again, who I've wanted to see so much.
og_response: Now, good Camillo;I am so fraught with curious business thatI leave out ceremony.

translated_dialog: Do you want a love song or a drinking song?
og_response: A love song, a love song.

translated_dialog: [To RODERIGO] Goodbye. I must leave you now. It seems to me neither wise nor appropriate given my position in Othello's service to be brought forward against the Moorand it seems like I will be, if I stay here. Besides, I know that the government cannot get rid of him (even if this whole thing may annoy Brabantio), since he's needed so greatly to fight in the wars with Cyprus that are going on right now. And the government has no one else of his capability to lead their forces, not even if they should trade their own souls for someone. Although I do hate Othello as much as I hate the tortures of Hell, for the time being I must show signs of lovewhich, I assure you, are nothing more than empty signs. You go lead the search party to the Sagittary Inn, where you will surely find him. I'll be there with him. So goodbye.
og_response: It is too true an evil. Gone she is.    And whats to come of my despisèd time    Is naught but bitterness. Now, Roderigo,    Where didst thou see her?   Oh, unhappy girl!    With the Moor, sayst thou?Who would be a father?    How didst thou know twas she?   Oh, she deceives me    Past thought!What said she to you?Get more tapers,    Raise all my kindred. Are they married, think you?

translated_dialog: Please, dear, come here.
og_response: What is your pleasure?

translated_dialog: I hope that a dew as evil as the one my mother used to gather from poison swamps and apply with a ravens feather will fall on top of you! May a hot wind from the southwest blow on you and cover you with blisters!
og_response: For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps,    Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up. Urchins    Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work,    All exercise on thee.   Thou shalt be pinched    As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging    Than bees that made 'em.

translated_dialog: Go after her, go after her.
og_response: I must, shell rail in the street else.

translated_dialog: I wish we could fight this very hour.
og_response: Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.

translated_dialog: Here comes the lords of Buckingham, and Derby.
og_response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]  Good time of day unto your royal Grace.

translated_dialog: Now, by all that's holy, here comes Katherina!
og_response: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

translated_dialog: I follow all your thoughts. What do you want?
og_response: Spirit,We must prepare to meet with Caliban.

translated_dialog: My only sin is my love for you.
og_response: Ay, and for that thou diest.

translated_dialog: Get him to bed, and make sure his wounds are tended to.
og_response: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman,    But, had it been the brother of my blood,    I must have done no less with wit and safety.    You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that    I do perceive it hath offended you.    Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows    We made each other but so late ago.

translated_dialog: Hello, neighbors.
og_response: Give you good morrow, sir.

translated_dialog: Madam, think of your son, the young prince, and be a careful mother. Send for him right away. Let him be crowned king. He is your hope for future peace of mind. Drown your desperate sorrows in dead Edward's grave, and plant your future joys in Prince Edward's new throne.
og_response: Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause    To wail the dimming of our shining star,    But none can help our harms by wailing them.    Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy;    I did not see your Grace.   Humbly on my knee    I crave your blessing.

translated_dialog: Tell me, heavenly rainbow, do you know if either Venus or her son Cupid are with the queen? Ever since the two of them plotted a way for Dis to steal from me my daughter Proserpina, I have sworn never to go near Venus or her blind son again.
og_response: Of her society    Be not afraid. I met her deity    Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son    Dove-drawn with her.   Here thought they to have done    Some wanton charm upon this man and maid,    Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid    Till Hymens torch be lightedbut in vain.    Marss hot minion is returned again.    Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows,    Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows    And be a boy right out.

translated_dialog: There's my glove, then. Descend now and open your gates. Those who were enemies of Timon and me you will hand over. They, and no one else, will die. And to calm your fear of me, no man of mine shall go beyond an assigned area, or disturb the peace within the city. If they do they will have to answer to harsh punishment.
og_response: 'Tis most nobly spoken.

translated_dialog: As we leave our friend, tossed into his grave, so too do those friends whose fortunes were tied to his now run away, leaving with him only their lies, like purses emptied by a pick-pocket. And the poor man will become a homeless beggar with his disease of poverty, walking alone in contempt. Look, here are more of our friends.
og_response: All broken implements of a ruin'd house.

translated_dialog: He's paid you all he owed you. He probably paid you too much, and you'll have to give something back.
og_response: Is there no manners left among maids? will they    wear their plackets where they should bear their    faces?   Is there not milking-time, when you are    going to bed, or kiln-hole, to whistle off these    secrets, but you must be tittle-tattling before all    our guests?   'tis well they are whispering: clamour    your tongues, and not a word more.

translated_dialog: Here comes someone in his night shirt, with a light and weapons.
